Review Recent progresses in the application of lignin derived (nano)catalysts in oxidation reactions Mahmoud Nasrollahzadeh * Nasrin Shafiei Zahra Nezafat Nayyereh Sadat Soheili Bidgoli Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Qom, Qom, 37185-359, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science University of Qom Qom 37185-359 Iran Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Qom, Qom 37185-359, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Recently, the attention to bio-based catalysts has been on rise. The present review explains the developments regarding preparation, characterization and utilization of lignin based (nano)catalysts in oxidation reactions. Herein, the application of lignin in the preparation of (nano)catalysts and their catalytic prowess in oxidative transformations will be overviewed. Lignin offers exceptional physicochemical characteristics and important potential applications. Lignin can be used as a precursor or template to prepare novel eco-friendly catalysts. This review paper proposes the rational design of active, economical, recyclable and efficient catalysts for different oxidation reactions including oxidation of alcohols, phenols, etc. Keywords Oxidation reactions Lignin Sustainable Heterogeneous catalyst Selective 1 Introduction Oxidation transformations have always been attractive to researchers as noteworthy and powerful methods for fundamental research or industrial scale productions. Oxidation of alkenes, alcohols, olefins, CO, and other organic agents to valuable oxygenic compounds is a significant reaction [1–10]. Traditionally, oxidation reactions have been performed using toxic oxidants including chromates, DMSO/(COCl)2, hypervalent iodine reagents, permanganates, and various metal catalysts along with oxidants including oxones, peroxides, TEMPO, etc. [11–16]. Various reports have been published on the catalytic oxidation transformations using metal based catalysts from the environmental and economic perspectives [17,18]. These reactions are often carried out by homogeneous catalysts, which cannot be removed from the reaction media or recovered and produce toxic wastes. One of the effective ways to overcome the drawbacks of homogeneous systems is the use of heterogeneous catalysis with exceptional properties such as high stability, insolubility in solvents, ease of handling, easy removal from the reaction media, recyclability and reusability, and the wide accessibility of the support [19–33]. Many researches have reported the use of polymer based systems as heterogeneous catalysts for chemical transformations [34–51]. Among polymer based catalysts, many research efforts have introduced novel, and ecofriendly biopolymer based catalytic systems for application in oxidation reactions. Common approaches have been replaced by fresh catalytic transformations [52]. Biopolymers are polymeric organic molecules containing monomeric parts bonded covalently to form larger molecules. They are formed by a range of plants, trees or microorganisms. They can decrease the utilization of non-renewable materials and minimize the environmental pollutions commonly caused by synthetic resources. The biodegradability and biocompatibility of these resources increases their areas of application [53–57]. Biopolymers have been recently known as attractive candidates to afford catalytic systems for various reactions including oxidation reactions. The synthesis of (nano)catalysts from this biopolymer presents an enormous opportunity for addressing the future catalytic demands [58]. Lignin is an industrial solid waste produced in large amounts by wood processing and pulp and paper production industries [59–61]. It mediates catalytic systems, which are economical and environmentally friendly. Such catalysts can mostly be recycled and reused for more than one catalytic run and show high efficacy towards oxidative transformations. In this review, the use of lignin derived (nano)catalysts for catalytic oxidation transformations has been highlighted. 2 Oxidizing agents An oxidizing agent is a compound with the capability to oxidize other agents, receive their electrons or transfer electronegative atoms, usually oxygen, to the system. The amount and kind of the oxidizing agent affect the reaction yield and conversion. Oxygen, hydrogen peroxide and halogens are known as the most common oxidants [34]. Some of the most common oxidizing agents are listed in Table 1 . Some of these compounds are utilized in combustion and organic redox reactions, while others retain their relatively explosive character [34]. Permanganate, a useful oxidizing agent, has limited solubility in non-polar media, which restricts its application for the oxidation of organic substrate in non-aqueous media. However, the permanganate combination with phase transfer catalysts makes it mild, selective and lipopathic and is useful for several important chemical transformations. The lipopathic permanganate oxidants oxidize several functional groups, including ethers, alkynes, alkenes, alkanes, alcohols, aldehydes, and oximes and have been applied in organic syntheses with regio, chemo and stereoselectivity [62]. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), an efficient and clean oxidant, has received wide attention given its high efficiency and environmental friendliness. Upon activation by transition metals, ultrasonication, microwave irradiation, electrolysis and light irradiation, H2O2 can be converted into high oxidative hydroxyl radicals (HO•), which play an important role in the removal of pollutants by H2O2 based advanced oxidation processes [63]. Molecular ozone (O3) has been utilized usually for cleansing and oxidation of various pollutants for environmental remediation. The decomposition of O3 in water, which is dependent on pH and is initiated by hydroxyl ion, followed by a series of reactions, leads to the generation of HO• radicals. These radicals are short lived and really potent oxidizing agent [64]. Different oxidizing agents have been used in oxidation reactions [65–72]. Some oxidants used in reactions including those, which cause combustion, are hazardous. Many kinds of the catalase enzymes along with sodium thiosulfate, manganese dioxide, sodium sulfite, ascorbic acid and sodium nitrite have been used in probed bioassays for quenching of oxidizing agents including hydrogen peroxide, persulfate and peroxymonosulfate in order to remove toxic agents. Permanganates, chromates, organic peroxides, etc. are known as toxic oxidants. However, there are also non-toxic oxidants. K2Cr2O7, for example, is not known as a toxic compound. On the contrary, hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)), which is one of the most common oxidants useful in various industrial procedures, is considered a harmful agent for human health. The development of catalytic supported oxidants is one advantageous approach to overcome the toxicity problem [73]. For example, poly[vinyl(pyridinium chlorochromate)] has been employed as a recyclable mild oxidant in the oxidation of various alcohols [74]. 3 Lignin chemistry Lignocellulosic biomass consists of hemicellulose, lignin and cellulose derived from grasses (miscanthus, switchgrass, etc.), softwoods (cedar, spruce, pine, etc.), hardwoods (poplar, birch, beech, etc.), and various agricultural wastes/byproducts (bagasse, husks, straws, etc.). Hemicellulose, a mixture of C6 and C5 polysaccharides, has significant applications in the fabrication of biofuel and important chemical intermediates such as furfural [75]. Cellulose, which is considered the most abundant biopolymers on earth, contains linear β(1-4) glucose chain links. This biopolymer can also be converted into valuable compounds such as biofuels, formic and levulinic acids, gamma-valerolactone and the corresponding derivatives [76]. Lignin is the third main part of lignocellulosic, which is the most utilized fraction for power and heat purposes via combustion in the paper and pulp industry because of its high calorific value. Among biopolymers, lignin has one of the complex structures and not shows various remarkable properties; specifically, insolubility in aqueous environment and its enzyme like activity can be remarkably decreased if not dissolved in organic solvents [77]. Biopolymers can be converted into various chemicals, which can be further transformed to cosmetics, fuels, engineering polymers, pharmaceuticals, etc. [78]. There are several pretreatment methods for the selective separation of each biomass component. Typically, these include chemical methods such as treatment with alkali compounds (NaOH), acids (HCl, H2SO4, H3PO4), ozone, oxidative treatment and organosolv [79–83] and physical methods such as milling [79,84,85], sometimes mixing with H2SO4, hydrothermal methods [86,87] and physicochemical such as SO2, ammonia fiber and steam explosion [79,88–90] and wet oxidation [91]. Lignin is the most abundant aromatic biopolymer after cellulose on the earth, occupying 15-40% of dry lignocellulosic biomass. It is one of the principal components of woody plants and is found in plant cell walls. Lignin acts as a binding agent by filling the space between hemicellulose and cellulose in the cell wall structure to tightly combine them [92]. Additionally, the presence of lignin in the plant promotes pathogenic defense and water transport [93]. Different reports have stated that the world's annual production of lignin differs from 40 to 50 million tons [59–61]. Thus, it is a very favorable method to depolymerize lignin to high value added and functional compounds [94]. Unfortunately, lignin is currently underutilized because of its biomass recalcitrance and enormous amounts of it is used as cheap solid fuel to make electricity and heat. Only 2% of pulping extracted lignin is utilized for other commercial purposes [95,96]. Generally, there are four main types of lignin; organosolv lignin, kraft lignin, lignosulfonate, and soda lignin, which can be directly extracted from grasses or woods in the pulp industry [93]. Considerable amounts of technical lignins such as lignosulfonates, kraft and hydrolysis lignin are prepared via the chemical processing of wood by the paper, pulping and hydrolysis industries. Moreover, lignin is the major source of natural aromatic structures in the world and is composed of aromatic monomers [94,96–97]. Various characterization methods such as scanning electron microscopy [98], gas chromatography-mass spectrometry [99], thermogravimetric analysis, infrared spectroscopy [100], transmission electron microscope (TEM), 13C/31P nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and heteronuclear single quantum coherence techniques [101] have been used to characterize lignin and its derivatives. Chemically, lignin is a linear and amorphous polymer composed of a random network of phenylpropane monomeric units; namely coniferyl alcohol (G), sinapyl (S), and p-coumaryl alcohols (H) and primary monolignols (Fig. 1 ) [96,102]. These units are linked to each other via C-C linkages such as β-1, 5-5', β-β, and aryl ether linkages counting β-O-4, 4-O-5 and dibenzodioxocin. Generally, β-O-4 is the main linkage (45-50%), while more than 12% of the linkages are β-5 phenylcoumaran bonds [103–105]. The usual bonding patterns in lignin are thus typically C-O-C bonds, which exist either as ethers or as part of a furan ring [106]. Additionally, typical functional groups in lignin include phenolic hydroxyl, aliphatic hydroxyl, methoxyl and other carbonyl groups. Lignin has many complexities compared with other constituents owing to its structure and the functional groups, which can be alkylated and acetylated as preferred in addition to undergoing several other reactions such as halogenation, nitration, reduction, oxidation, sulfonation, hydrolysis, catalytic hydrogenation under pressure, and fusion with metals or alkali compounds. Lignin is usually depolymerized to develop novel monomers [107], but some complexities exist as it is powerfully held together by some of the strongest bonds (C-C and C-O) and further structural characteristics are influenced by the approaches used in its extraction. These approaches include Björkman process [108], cellulolytic enzyme lignin, enzymatic mild acidolysis lignin [109,110], organosolv process [111] and ionic liquid treatment [112]. In addition, the starting materials affect the properties, structures and chemistry of lignin [113]. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and lignin are the significant biopolymers in woody biomass, which are extensively used as starting materials in the preparation of functional polymers and composites. Lignin biopolymers can be broadly used in different fields owing to several properties such as biodegradability, high thermal stability, antimicrobial actions, adhesive nature, antioxidant properties and so on. Lignocellulose fibers are natural, earth-abundant, inexpensive, promising compounds to produce supports for catalysts due to their rich surface functional groups such as methoxy, hydroxyl (OH), carbonyl (C = O), and carboxyl (COOH) groups, which can promote the dispersion and deposition of metal nanoparticles (NPs). Some workers have reported the fabrication of NPs such as Cu, Pt, Pd, Au, or Ag on cellulose polymers [114–117]. Generally, the use of lignocellulose fibers and lignin biomass as catalyst supports can lead to the enhanced stabilization of NPs. Important examples of different lignin based (nano)catalysts and their catalytic applications have been reported in recent years [118–124]. For example, recently, the activity of lignin based (nano)catalysts was evaluated in our research group in Cr(VI) reduction, hydrogen storage and Suzuki-Miyaura reaction in eco-friendly media [53,123,124]. 4 Lignin derived (nano)catalysts in the oxidation reactions In recent decade, lignin based (nano)catalysts have been used as heterogeneous and novel catalysts with excellent catalytic prowess for chemical transformations. Different applications of lignin based (nano)catalysts in the oxidation reactions are summarized in this section. In 2019, Liu et al. reported the pyrolysis of dicyandiamide and Co/Mn-lignin complex mixture to prepare novel Mn/N co-doped carbon supported Co (Co-Mn/N@C) nanocatalyst for selective oxidation of HMF (5-hydroxymethylfurfural) in the air to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) (Fig. 2 ) [125]. The research group found that the Mn/N-doped carbon can increase the reactivity of Co NPs (Fig. 3 ). In this reaction, H2O is a source of oxygen of FDCA and O2 acts as an electron scavenger and removes protons for to regenerate the catalyst. Conversion of biomass derived lignin and HMF demonstrates the value of renewable wastes. In the same year, Jiang et al. prepared single-atom catalysts on nitrogen-doped carbon (M SAs-N@C, in which M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) via a robust and facile metal-lignin coordination process (Fig. 4 ) [126]. The Co SAs-N@C catalyst affords excellent reactivity in the oxidative esterification of primary alcohols. Co SAs-N@C catalyst also converts HMF directly to dimethyl furan-2,5-dicarboxylate (FDE). This method is facile, economical and scalable. Furthermore, Pt supported on lignin based carbon dots (Pt/Lg-CDs) was prepared by Li and co-workers via the chloroplatinic acid reduction in a solution of carbon dots in 2019 [127]. Optimal Pt/Lg-CDs-800 catalyst showed more stability and activity than PtRu/C (30% Pt + 15% Ru) and Pt/C (40% Pt) in the methanol electro-oxidation. In 2018, Saladino and co-workers functionalized lignin nanoparticles with tyrosinase for oxidizing phenol derivatives under eco-friendly conditions [128]. It was observed that lignin was stable to the tyrosinase activity. The as-synthesized catalyst helped in the synthesis of catechol derivatives (Scheme 1 ), where the efficiency of the catalyst refers to the immobilization processes. Tyrosinase immobilization was carried out via direct adsorption process, followed by encapsulation, and layer-by-layer deposition, with or without glutaraldehyde reticulation. In another study in the same year, Ma et al. encapsulated nanoscale zero-valent iron (ZVI) in lignin derived hydrochar (Fe@HC) via a facile one-pot, cheap and environmentally friendly, in situ method [129]. Fe@HC-800 can degrade phenol completely within 20 minutes at mild temperatures using peroxymonosulfate (PMS) (Scheme 2 ). The catalyst also exhibits high stability even after 3 runs. The research team of Rodríguez-Mirasol prepared platinum loaded lignin fibers with and without phosphorus via one-step electrospinning of lignin/phosphoric acid/ethanol/platinum acetylacetonate solutions in 2017 [130]. Thanks to thermochemical treatments, lignin based carbon fiber electrocatalysts were obtained with high and low Pt concentration, stabilized in the air and carbonized at the temperature of 900 °C in nitrogen atmosphere. Carbon fiber electrodes afford high surface areas with well dispersed Pt NPs. The electrodes, which contain Pt, exhibit higher surface area, smaller Pt particle size and good particle distribution and thus better oxidation and electro-oxidation activity than those with no P. The activity of the as-obtained catalyst was shown to be outstanding in the oxidation of methanol and ethanol. Furthermore, activated carbon derived from hemp and wheat lignin was prepared by Martin-Martinez et al. by carbonization at 800 °C in nitrogen atmosphere [131]. The consequential components were applied as catalysts in the 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) oxidative degradation using catalytic wet peroxide oxidation (CWPO) via decomposing H2O2. At low temperatures, fast but inefficient H2O2 decomposition was observed, which suggests the production of species other than HO•. Increasing the temperature was observed to complete 4-NP removal. In 2016, β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) attached to lignin (L-β-CD) was prepared by Ji and co-workers via the reaction of β-CD and lignin using epichlorohydrin (EPI) as a cross-linker (Scheme 3 ) [132]. The as prepared catalyst was then applied in benzyl alcohol (BzOH) oxidation to benzaldehyde (BzH) with good selectivity using H2O2 as the oxidant (Scheme 4 ). The best conditions for the reaction, which yields high selectivity (>99%) and the probable mechanism for the reaction (Scheme 5 ) were discussed. The weak interactions between the catalyst and support affected efficient oxidation reaction of BzOH. Recyclability with no loss of catalytic activity was the advantage of the catalyst, which extends its use for green synthesis of BzH. In another study, Rodríguez-Mirasol and colleagues synthesized carbon based Pd catalysts with low Pd content (0.5%) by using mesoporous activated carbons obtained from kraft lignin activated with H3PO4 [133]. The activation of the produced carbon supports limit their oxidation due to large amounts of surface phosphorus, in form of C-PO3, C-O-PO3 and C3PO groups. The prepared catalysts were used in the oxidation of benzene, toluene and xylene at 150-400 °C. The catalysts obtained displayed high mesopores volumes and surface areas. TEM study showed that Pd NPs had been suitably dispersed in size of 5-12 nm. In 2019, Piccinino et al. reported the laccase immobilization on lignin NPs by encapsulation, physical adsorption, and layer by layer (LbL) technologies, containing the glutaraldehyde and bovine derum albumin process (Fig. 5 ) [134]. The new catalysts converted alcohols to aldehydes with high selectivity by 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-yloxyl (TEMPO) as a redox mediator (Scheme 6 and Table 2 ). Most recently, Pylypchuk and co-workers prepared the magnetic encapsulated lignin peroxidase (LiP) and horseradish peroxidase (HRP) composites via adsorption of the peroxidase enzymes on Fe3O4 surface, followed by the formation of SiO2 shell via sol-gel process (Fig. 6 ) [135]. Encapsulation improved the biocatalyst stability. The synthesized biocatalysts were used in the oxidation of diclofenac, carbamazepine, and paracetamol pollutants. The sol-gel encapsulated HRP and LiP based composites were active over 20 repeated cycles at 55 °C for 20 days (24 h/cycle). Diclofenac and carbamazepine were degraded to 64% and 68%, respectively, by F3O4/LP/SiO2 at pH 5. Complete degradation of diclofenac and carbamazepine was reached at 55 °C (pH 3) within 72 h for both immobilized LiP and HRP. There have also been other studies regarding the application of the lignin based catalysts in oxidation processes, which are summarized in Table 3 . 5 Conclusion and future prospects Despite the benefits of the prepared catalysts from non-renewable resources, they have often failed for commercialization due to their high production cost and environmental pollution. In order to decrease the environmental pollution by synthetic compounds and the use of non-renewable materials and resources, the search for using biomaterials is on growth. Among biomaterials, biopolymer based resources are safely and efficiently prepared via a green route. These compounds, which are valuable in nanoscience, sensors, catalysis, water treatment, biomedical application, cancer treatment, energy sector, antibacterial material, food industry and other fields can be prepared easily from the plant and animal wastes of otherwise no economic value. Biopolymers have revolutionized the improvement of biocatalysts. They are also used as stabilizers and reducers in metal ion reduction to metal NPs and their stabilization. Both biocompatibility and biodegradability of these materials are important characteristics, which have expanded their applications. A biopolymer can be combined with various compounds such as a biopolymer or a biodegradable synthetic polymer to generate an effective composite as a catalyst. In addition, the immobilization of metal nanoparticles or complexes such as Ag, Cu, Pd, TiO2, ZnO, Au, etc. on the surface of biopolymers forms stable compounds with enhanced catalytic prowess. The recent studies have demonstrated the true potential of lignin based catalysts in oxidation reactions. These catalytic systems afford environmentally friendly catalysts for oxidative transformation reactions, which can replace the conventional hazardous catalysts. Catalysts based on lignin have been outstanding to the researchers owing to their important characteristics such as facile and simple synthesis method, low price, recyclability, stability and environmental friendliness, which have extended their use in oxidation reactions. They can be also efficient in such reactions owing to their high surface area, high porosity, small size, low amount and uniform dispersion of nanoparticles and no release of particles into the mixture of the reaction. Lignin based catalysts can catalyze a variety of oxidation reactions. Catalyst assisted oxidative transformation reactions have been mostly carried out with the aim of synthesis or removal of pollutants. These catalysts present excellent catalytic activities in the oxidation reactions. Despite recent improvements in lignin based catalysts, there are several challenges, which need to be investigated in future studies: • Technological improvements and controlled environmental conditions for the easy preparation of biopolymers, including lignin, from available raw materials. • Utilization of different bio-wastes for the preparation of biopolymers. • Reported methods for the preparation of lignin based catalysts in this review were small in scale. Consequently, we believe there are great potentials for the fabrication of these catalysts in industrial scale. • The utilization of plant extracts for the immobilization of metal NPs on the biopolymers surface under green and mild conditions • Development of efficient approaches for the organization of magnetic lignin based catalyst due to their easy separation from the reaction media. coredata.dc:description: Recently, the attention to bio-based catalysts has been on rise. The present review explains the developments regarding preparation, characterization and utilization of lignin based (nano)catalysts in oxidation reactions. Herein, the application of lignin in the preparation of (nano)catalysts and their catalytic prowess in oxidative transformations will be overviewed. Lignin offers exceptional physicochemical characteristics and important potential applications. Lignin can be used as a precursor or template to prepare novel eco-friendly catalysts. This review paper proposes the rational design of active, economical, recyclable and efficient catalysts for different oxidation reactions including oxidation of alcohols, phenols, etc.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progresses in the application of lignin derived (nano)catalysts in oxidation reactions
